author: Devesh K
text:
The Central Bureau of Investigation has registered a case against eight officials of the National Institute of Pharmaceutical Education and Research (NIPER) in Punjab for allegedly purchasing access licences for a global patent data base from a Pune-based firm at an exorbitant rate. The accused caused a loss of Rs.10 crore.

According to the CBI, the company named Sciedge Informatics usually charged $36,000 for annual licences to access the database software “Scifinder”, but it allegedly charged $51,000 per year to NIPER between 2007 and 2012.

Among those named are the then director, officiating director, registrar, the then deputy registrar, chief vigilance officer, officiating registrar, the section officer, a deputy registrar and a professor of the institute. The firm has also been named in the case registered under various provisions of the Prevention of Corruption Act and the Indian Penal Code.

Following a complaint, the CBI had earlier instituted a preliminary inquiry into the allegations of collusion by the accused officials. “The NIPER officials in question allegedly entered into a criminal conspiracy with the firm for the purchase of database ‘SciFinder’ on exorbitant rates causing loss to the exchequer,” said a CBI official. It was also alleged that some unknown private persons and officials of the Ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers were involved in misappropriation of funds, falsification of accounts and diversion of funds from approved projects.

Based on the findings, the CBI registered the case and conducted searches on Friday at 22 places.
title: CBI books eight NIPER officials on graft charge
